TONIGHT ON THE CBS
  EVENING NEWS

Here is an early
  preview of what Awe are planning for tonight’s CBS EVENING NEWS from
  Anchor and Managing Editor, Katie Couric… 

  Hi everyone, 

  Today, the investigation continues into the tragedy at Virginia Tech and, of
  course, our correspondents are on the scene covering every angle. 

  A picture of Cho Seung-Hui is slowly emerging: he was a solitary young man
  with few friends. But his bizarre behavior had been noticed – two women
  at Virginia Tech say they raised concerns in 2005 about Cho’s repeated
  attempts to contact them. When can a school take steps against a student it
  suspects might someday cause harm? Cynthia
  Bowers will have the details. 

  The paper trail Cho left behind helps fill in the picture. Sharyn Alfonsi will report on Cho’s
  alarming creative writing pieces, the ranting note he left behind and the
  latest on the investigation into Monday’s massacre. 

  A significant part of that investigation hinges on forensic evidence, and
  some of that is locked inside the computer Cho owned and used. Technology correspondent
  Daniel Sieberg will report on
  how authorities are extracting information from the gunman’s hard
  drive. 

  Also, Thalia Assuras will have
  an emotional interview with a young woman who lives near the site of the
  first shooting Monday. It’s a dramatic account. 

  In other news, the Supreme Court upheld the country’s ban on certain
  abortions this morning. The justices ruled 5-4 that the Partial Birth
  Abortion Ban Act that Congress passed and President Bush signed four yeas ago
  is constitutionally sound. Wyatt Andrews
  will have more on the decision. Our chief legal analyst, Andrew Cohen, will also weigh in on the
  implications of the decision. 

  Finally, it has been an extraordinarily deadly day in Baghdad, where more than 175 people were
  killed in a series of bombings – the worst day of violence since the
  American troop surge began a few months ago. Martin Seemungal will report. 

I hope you’ll join us. 

Katie

THURSDAY MORNING ON THE EARLY
  SHOW

Harry Smith
  and Kelly Wallace will anchor THE EARLY SHOW from
  Blacksburg, VA. Russ
  Mitchell anchors from New
    York. Dave Price
  will bring us the weather. Hannah Storm
  and Julie Chen are off. 

  We will continue to cover the "MASSACRE
  AT VIRGINIA
  TECH". 

  We will have the latest on the allegations that Cho Seung-Hui had engaged in
  stalking behavior, reaction from students, and how the injured are
  recovering. Including: 

STUDENT REACTION: Shot in the
  massacre, Garrett Evans may never be the same. That is because doctors have
  made the decision to leave the bullet in his injured leg. How is Garrett
  coping through the pain? We'll speak with him Wednesday morning. 

STUDENT REACTION CONTINUES:
  We'll speak with a fellow English major who was enrolled in the same
  playwriting class as Cho. What were the signs in Cho's writing? We'll find
  out Wednesday morning. 

COLUMBINE ANNIVERSARY: School
  shootings are nothing new. As we approach the anniversary of Columbine, we'll
  speak with a parent who knows all too well what it is like to lose a child in
  such a horrific tragedy. Tom Mauser will join us.
